meanings_list.meaning: formally reject or give up (as a belief)
meanings_list.example: While the church believed that Galileo abjured the heliocentric theory under threat of torture, he later wrote a book clearly supporting the theory.
As part of the agreement between the labor union and the company, the workers abrogated their right to strike for four years in exchange for better health insurance.

meanings_list.meaning: to serve as a judge in a competition; to arrive at a judgment or conclusion
meanings_list.example: Only those with the most refined palates were able to adjudicate during the barbeque competition.
The summit of Mt. Kilimanjaro affords a panoramic view that encompasses both Tanzania and Kenya. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: an eager willingness to do something
meanings_list.example: The first three weeks at his new job, Mark worked with such alacrity that upper management knew it would be giving him a promotion.

meanings_list.meaning: something that is inappropriate for the given time period (usually something old).
meanings_list.example: Dressed in 15th century clothing each day, Edward was a walking anachronism.

meanings_list.meaning: a detested person; the source of somebody's hate
meanings_list.example: Hundreds of years ago, Galileo was anathema to the church; today the church is anathema to some on the left side of the political spectrum.
After three straight shows, the lead actress gave an anemic performance the fourth night, barely speaking loudly enough for those in the back rows to hear.

meanings_list.meaning: something that soothes or relieves pain
meanings_list.example: Muzak, which is played in department stores, is intended to be an anodyne, but is often so cheesy and over-the-top that customers become irritated.
Wilbur enjoyed a spicy Mexican breakfast, but Jill prefered a far more anodyne meal in the mornings.
The clown's antic act was too extreme for the youngest children, who left the room in tears. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: great coolness and composure under strain
meanings_list.example: Nancy acted with aplomb during dangerous situations--she once calmly climbed up an oak tree to save a cat.
The apogee of the Viennese style of music, Mozart's music continues to mesmerize audiences well into the 21st century.

meanings_list.meaning: a person who has abandoned a religious faith or cause
meanings_list.example: An apostate of the Republican Party, Sheldon has yet to become affiliated with any party and dubs himself an independent.
Winston Churchill is famous for many apothegms, but this might be his most famous: "It has been said that democracy is the worst form of government except all the others that have been tried."

meanings_list.meaning: exaltation to divine status; the highest point of development
meanings_list.example: As difficult as it is to imagine, the apotheosis of Mark Zuckerberg's career, many believe, is yet to come.
Although it might not be her best work, Hunter's new novel has received generally approbatory reviews.

meanings_list.meaning: to give or take something by force
meanings_list.example: The government appropriated land that was occupied by squatters, sending them scurrying for another place to live. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE
The committe appropriated the funds to its various members. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE
In hiking Mt. Everest, sherpas are appurtenant, helping climbers both carry gear and navigate treacherous paths.

The baroness was arch, making playful asides to the townspeople; yet because they couldn't pick up on her dry humor, they thought her supercilious. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: complete and wholly (usually modifying a noun with negative connotation)
meanings_list.example: An arrant fool, Lawrence surprised nobody when he lost all his money in a pyramid scheme that was every bit as transparent as it was corrupt.

meanings_list.meaning: a person who has recently reached a position of power; a social climber
meanings_list.example: The city center was aflutter with arrivistes who each tried to outdo one another with their ostentatious sports cars and chic evening dress.
Arriving at the small town, the outlaw arrogated the privileges of a lord, asking the frightened citizens to provide food, drink, and entertainment.

meanings_list.meaning: cunning tricks used to deceive others
meanings_list.example: The mayoral candidates both spent much of the campaign accusing each other of artifices designed to mislead the voting public.
Despite the president's seemingly artless speeches, he was a skilled and ruthless negotiator.
I, personally, found the artlessness of her speech charming.
The editor was known for his asperity, often sending severe letters of rejection to amateur writers.
The top college football program recruits new talent assiduously, only choosing those who were the top in their county.

meanings_list.meaning: a reappearance of an earlier characteristic; throwback
meanings_list.example: Much of the modern art movement was an atavism to a style of art found only in small villages through Africa and South America.

meanings_list.meaning: to weaken (in terms of intensity); to taper off/become thinner.
meanings_list.example: Her animosity towards Bob attenuated over the years, and she even went so far as to invite him to her party.

meanings_list.meaning: characteristic of an absolute ruler or absolute rule; having absolute sovereignty
meanings_list.example: The last true autocratic country is certainly North Korea; nowhere does a leader exercise the absolute control over all aspects of a people the way that Kim Jong-un does.

meanings_list.meaning: offensively self-assured or given to exercising usually unwarranted power
meanings_list.example: The manager was finally fired for his autocratic leadership, which often bordered on rude and offensive.

meanings_list.meaning: threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments
meanings_list.example: Movies often use storms or rain clouds as a baleful omen of evil events that will soon befall the main character.

meanings_list.meaning: the lowest, class were without any moral principles
meanings_list.example: She was not so base as to begrudge the beggar the unwanted crumbs from her dinner plate. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: an act that debases or corrupts
meanings_list.example: The movie World War Z is a complete bastardization of the book with little more in common than zombies and a title.

By assuming that Charlie was headed to college--which he was not--Maggie begged the question when she asked him to which school he was headed in the Fall. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: express discontent or a stong regret
meanings_list.example: While the CFO carefully explained all the reasons for the cuts in benefits, after the meeting employees bemoaned the cuts as further evidence that management was against them.

meanings_list.meaning: fallen into a state of ignorance
meanings_list.example: Far from being a period of utter benightedness, The Medieval Ages produced some great works of theological speculation.

meanings_list.meaning: unhappy in love; suffering from unrequited love
meanings_list.example: After 64 years of marriage, William was bereft after the death of his wife.
You are not bereft if you haven't played on your Xbox in the past week, his mother said.
Even though her father did not approve, Juliet became besotted with the young Romeo.
Never before have I seen my mom so besotted, and honestly, I hope it's the last time she drinks so much.
Rex was bilious all morning, and his face would only take on a look of contentedness when he'd had his morning cup of coffee.

meanings_list.meaning: to have a limited outlook or understanding
meanings_list.example: In gambling, the addict is easily blinkered by past successes and/or past failures, forgetting that the outcome of any one game is independent of the games that preceded it.

meanings_list.meaning: edit by omitting or modifying parts considered indelicate
meanings_list.example: To recieve an R rating, the entire movie was bowdlerized because it contained so much violence and grotesque subject matter.

meanings_list.meaning: the act of restraining power or action or limiting excess
meanings_list.example: New curfew laws have bridled people's tendency to go out at night.
The hostess bridled at the tactless dinner guests who insisted on eating before everybody had gotten their food.

meanings_list.meaning: react in an offended or angry manner
meanings_list.example: As we discussed the painting, I noticed the artitst's wife bristling at our criticisms, ready to defend her husband's work.
Political broadsides are usually strongest in the weeks leading up to a national election.
Instead of sharing his umbrella, the cheeky stranger offered Martha the following bromide: "Looks like it's raining."

meanings_list.meaning: put up with something or somebody unpleasant
meanings_list.example: While she was at the chalkboard, the teacher did not brook any form of talking--even a tiny peep resulted in afternoon detention. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: be bossy towards; discourage or frighten with threats or a domineering manner
meanings_list.example: During the interrogation, the suspect was browbeaten into signing a false confession.
Getting a driver's license is not simply a matter of taking a test; the regulations and procedures are so byzantine that many have found themselves at the mercy of the Department of Motor Vehicles.
Both Los Angeles and New York are known for callow out-of-towners hoping to make it big.
The public will always be fooled by the media's canards.
Paul, losing 19-0 in a ping-pong match against his nimble friend, basically capitulated when he played the last two points with his eyes closed.

meanings_list.meaning: an event resulting in great loss and misfortune
meanings_list.example: The introduction of smallpox was a cataclysm for Native Americans, killing off more than half of their population.

Jonah's friends said that Jonah's taste in music was eclectic; Jonah was quick to point out that not only was his taste eclectic but it was also catholic: he enjoyed music from countries as far-flung as Mali and Mongolia.
Eventually, all parents must cede control of their growing childrens' educations and allow their offspring some autonomy.
We aim to respond to customers' questions with celerity and accuracy, with no longer than a 24 hour wait time.
Much to the the timid writer's chagrin, the audience chanted his name until he came back on the stage.

meanings_list.meaning: cause to feel shame; hurt the pride of
meanings_list.example: She never cared what others said about her appearance but was chagrined by the smallest comment from her mother.

meanings_list.meaning: a flamboyant deceiver; one who attracts customers with tricks or jokes
meanings_list.example: You may call him a "motivational speaker," but I call him a charlatan--he doesn't have any idea what he's really talking about.
Jack was wary of GRE words that looked similar, because they usually had different definitions; not so with chary, a word that he began to use interchangeably with wary.

meanings_list.meaning: fanatical patriotism; belief that one's group/cause is superior to all other
meanings_list.example: groups/causes Vegetarians argue that man is chauvinistic in his belief that animals do not consciously feel the pain we humans do. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: something desired or wished for but is only an illusion and impossible to achieve
meanings_list.example: Many believe that a world free of war is a chimera--a dream that ignores humanity's violent tendancies. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: prone to outbursts of temper; easily angered
meanings_list.example: While a brilliant lecturer, Mr. Dawson came across as choleric and unapproachable--very rarely did students come to his office hours.
The manager was unnecessarily churlish to his subordinates, rarely deigning to say hello, but always quick with a sartorial jab if someone happened to be wearing anything even slightly mismatching.

meanings_list.meaning: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others
meanings_list.example: On her first day at the job, Annie was complaisant, fulfilling every request of her new employee and anticipating future requests.

meanings_list.meaning: Associated with or participating in an activity, especially one of a questionable
meanings_list.example: nature. While the grand jury cleared the senator of all criminal charges, in the public mind he was still complicit in the corruption.
His opponents believed his gesture to be conciliatory, yet as soon as they put down their weapons, he unsheathed a hidden sword.

meanings_list.meaning: describing an event or situation that happens at the same time as or in
meanings_list.example: connection with another Concomitant with his desire for nature was a desire for the culture and energy of a big city.

meanings_list.meaning: a very intense and uncontrolled fire
meanings_list.example: In the summer months, conflagrations are not uncommon in the southwest, do to the heat and lack of rain.

meanings_list.meaning: mix together different elements or concepts
meanings_list.example: In her recent book, the author conflates several genres--the detective story, the teen thriller, and the vampire romance--to create a memorable read.
Since old grandpa Harry became very contentious during the summer when only reruns were on T.V., the grandkids learned to hide from him at every opportunity.

meanings_list.meaning: a practical consequence that follows naturally
meanings_list.example: A corollary of Hurricane Sandy, which ravaged the east coast of the U.S., is a push to build higher sea walls to protect against future hurricanes.
The king and queen cosseted the young prince, giving him a prized miniature pony for his fifth birthday.

meanings_list.meaning: being of equal extent or scope or duration
meanings_list.example: The border of the state is coterminous with geographic limits on travel; the east and north are surrounded by a nearly uncrossable river and the south by a desert.

meanings_list.meaning: a contrary command cancelling or reversing a previous command
meanings_list.example: By the time the colonel countermanded his soldiers not to land in enemy territory, a few helicopters had already touched down amid heavy gunfire.
Do not be cowed by a 3,000-word vocabulary list: turn that list into a deck of flashcards! This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE
I asked Maria on a date and she refused without a moment's thought; I was crestfallen.

meanings_list.meaning: cause to take on a definite and clear shape
meanings_list.example: Only after fifteen minutes of brainstorming did Samantha's ideas for the essay crystallize. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE
Some believe people that amassing as much wealth as possible is the meaning to life--yet they often realize that cupidity brings anything but happiness.

James Bond is known for his good looks, high tech gadgets, and debonair manner.
The entire audience erupted in shouts and curses, decrying the penalty card issued by the referee.

meanings_list.meaning: to help pay the cost of, either in part of full
meanings_list.example: In order for Sean to attend the prestigious college, his generous uncle helped defray the excessive tuition with a monthly donation.

meanings_list.meaning: do something that one considers to be below one's dignity
meanings_list.example: The master of the house never deigned to answer questions from the servants.

meanings_list.meaning: given to or marked by the open expression of emotion
meanings_list.example: When Sally told James that she wanted to break up with him, she expected he would react demonstratively, but he quietly nodded his head and left without saying a word.

meanings_list.meaning: the final resolution of the many strands of a literary or dramatic work; the
meanings_list.example: outcome of a complex sequence of events At the denouement of the movie, all questions were answered, and the true identity of the robber was revealed.

meanings_list.meaning: (of a person) not doing one's duties
meanings_list.example: The teacher was derelict in her duties because she hadn't graded a single student paper in three weeks.
At one time the waterfront factories were busy and productive, but now they stand derelict and will be torn down.
Few novelists over 80 are able to produce anything more than desiccated works--boring shadows of former books. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE
The desideratum of the environmental group is that motorists should rely on carpooling.
The Emperor Claudius was regarded as a fair-minded leader; his successor, Nero, was an absolute despot.

meanings_list.meaning: a strong verbal attack against a person or institution
meanings_list.example: Steve's mom launched into a diatribe during the PTA meeting, contending that the school was little more than a daycare in which students stare at the wall and teachers stare at the chalkboard.
He prefers to be called a diminutive of his name: "Bill" instead of "John William."
When he put on his father's suit and shoes, his appearance was that of a diminutive youth.

meanings_list.meaning: to persuade somebody that his/her belief is not valid
meanings_list.example: As a child, I was quickly disabused of the notion that Santa Claus was a rotund benefactor of infinite largess--one night I saw my mother diligently wrapping presents and storing them under our Christmas tree.

meanings_list.meaning: (of e.g. speech and writing) tending to depart from the main point
meanings_list.example: Many readers find it tough to read Moby Dick since the author is discursive, often cutting the action short to spend 20 pages on the history of a whale.

meanings_list.meaning: not straightforward; giving a false appearance of frankness
meanings_list.example: Many adults think that they can lie to children, but kids are smart and know when people are disingenuous.

meanings_list.meaning: an exemption from a rule or obligation
meanings_list.example: Since her father is a billionaire, she is given dispensation from many of the school's policies. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: conceal one's true motives, usually through deceit
meanings_list.example: To get close to the senator, the assassin dissembled his intentions, convincing many people that he was a reporter for a well-known newspaper.
The recent graduates dissipated their earnings on trips to Las Vegas and cruises in Mexico.
Kathleen's perfume was overwhelming in the cramped apartment, but once we stepped outside the smell dissipated and we could breathe once again.

meanings_list.meaning: a living full of debauchery and indulgence in sensual pleasure
meanings_list.example: Many Roman emporers were known for their dissolution, indulging in unspeakable desires of the flesh. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

Chopin's ballades are filled with sharp changes in moods--a dolorous melody can give way to a lighthearted tempo.
I enjoy films in which a doughty group comes together to battle a force of evil.

meanings_list.meaning: fit together tightly, as if by means of a interlocking joint
meanings_list.example: Although Darwin's evolution and Mendel's genetics were developed in isolation from one another, they dovetail each other very well. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: deceitfulness, pretending to want one thing but interested in something else
meanings_list.example: A life of espionage is one of duplicity: an agent must pretend to be a totally different person than who she or he actually is.
Can you blame him for his ebullient mood? He just graduated from medical school.

meanings_list.meaning: marked by high spirits or excitement
meanings_list.example: After the sales result, the manager was in an effervescent mood, letting several employees leave work early that day. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: audacious (even arrogant) behavior that you have no right to
meanings_list.example: The skateboarders acted with effrontery, skating through the church grounds and spray-painting signs warning trespassers.

meanings_list.meaning: in an early stage of development
meanings_list.example: The Board of Directors is hoping to launch a new product soon, but planning for the Z7 is in an embryonic stages. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: any method that derives knowledge from experience, used in experimental science
meanings_list.example: as a way to gain insight and knowledge Empiricism does not always lead to knowledge; an experience or experiment may raise more questions than it answers.
She is completely enamored with Justin Bieber, and goes to all his concerts on the East coast.
The costume encumbered all my movements and caused me to sweat profusely.

meanings_list.meaning: give instructions to or direct somebody to do something with authority
meanings_list.example: The government agency enjoined the chemical company to clean up the hazardous dump it had created over the years.

meanings_list.meaning: a sudden revelation or moment of insight
meanings_list.example: Gary one day had an epiphany that he was a people person; he prompty quit his factory job and began working as a salesman.

meanings_list.meaning: the name derived from a person (real or imaginary); the person for whom something is
meanings_list.example: named Alexandria, Egypt is an eponym because it is named after Alexander the Great.

meanings_list.meaning: fair to all parties as dictated by reason and conscience
meanings_list.example: The equitable distribution of ice cream to a group of 5 year olds will ensure little to no fighting--at least until the ice cream is gone.

meanings_list.meaning: to speak vaguely, usually with the intention to mislead or deceive
meanings_list.example: After Sharon brought the car home an hour after her curfew, she equivocated when her parents pointedly asked her where she had been.

After serving thirty years, in which he selflessly served the community, Judge Harper was one of the more estimable people in town.
Because she dances with an ethereal style, ballet critics have called her Madame Butterfly.

meanings_list.meaning: critical explanation or analysis, especially of a text
meanings_list.example: The Bible is fertile ground for exegesis--over the past five centuries there have been as many interpretations as there are pages in the Old Testament.

After two months at sea, the exiguity of the ship's supplies forced them to search for fresh water and food.

meanings_list.meaning: greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation
meanings_list.example: Shelley made one exorbitant purchase after another, buying new clothes and taking vacations even though she earned a limited salary.

meanings_list.meaning: communicative, and prone to talking in a sociable manner
meanings_list.example: After a few sips of cognac, the octogenarian shed his irascible demeanor and became expansive, speaking fondly of the "good old days". This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

The censor expurgated every reference to sex and drugs, converting the rapper's raunchy flow into a series of bleeps.

meanings_list.meaning: draw from specific cases for more general cases
meanings_list.example: By extrapolating from the data on the past three months, we can predict a 5% increase in traffic to our website.

meanings_list.meaning: arrived at without due care or effort; lacking depth
meanings_list.example: Many news shows provide facile explanations to complex politics, so I prefer to read the in-depth reporting of The New York Times.

meanings_list.meaning: produced by, or characterized by internal dissension
meanings_list.example: The controversial bill proved factious, as dissension even within parties resulted
The defendant's story was largely factitious and did not accord with eyewitness testimonies

meanings_list.meaning: be a mystery or bewildering to

meanings_list.meaning: irritable and is likely to cause disruption
meanings_list.example: We rarely invite my fractious Uncle over for dinner; he always complains about the food, and usually launches into a tirade on some touchy subject.

meanings_list.example: In a famous gaffe, Vice President Quayle attempted to correct the spelling of a grade school student, only to find that the child was correct.

meanings_list.example: Years ago, savvy politicians had gerrymandered the city center to ensure their re-election.

meanings_list.meaning: excessively flattering toward someone's life or work
meanings_list.example: Most accounts of Tiger Woods life were hagiographic, until, that is, his affairs made headlines.

meanings_list.meaning: idyllically calm and peaceful; suggesting happy tranquillity; marked by peace and
meanings_list.example: prosperity The first decade after WWI was a halcyon period in America with new-found wealth and rapidly improving technology.

meanings_list.meaning: overbearing pride evidenced by a superior manner toward inferiors
meanings_list.example: As soon as she won the lottery, Alice begin displaying a hauteur to her friends, calling them dirty-clothed peasants behind their backs.

meanings_list.meaning: to limit or qualify a statement; to avoid making a direct statement
meanings_list.example: When asked why he had decided to buy millions of shares at the very moment the tech companies stock soared, the CEO hedged, mentioning something vague about gut instinct. This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

meanings_list.meaning: to hold back the progress of something
meanings_list.example: Bad weather has hobbled rescue efforts, making it difficult for crews to find bodies in the wreckage.
Someone tried to hoodwink Marty with an email telling him that his uncle had just passed away, and to collect the inheritance he should send his credit card information.

meanings_list.meaning: widely known and esteemed; having or conferring glory
meanings_list.example: Einstein was possibly the most illustrious scientist in recent history.

meanings_list.meaning: to drink or absorb as if drinking
meanings_list.example: Plato imbibed Socrates' teachings to such an extent that he was able to write volumes of work that he directly attributed, sometimes word for word, to Socrates.

meanings_list.meaning: a confusing and potentially embarrassing situation

meanings_list.meaning: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as

meanings_list.meaning: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected
meanings_list.example: I am not impervious to your insults; they cause me great pain.

meanings_list.meaning: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation
meanings_list.example: Herbert is rarely impetuous, but on the spur of the moment, he spent thousands of dollars on a motorcycle today.

meanings_list.meaning: total lack of meaning or ideas
meanings_list.example: Bill's poem was nothing more than a list of impressive sounding words, so there was no point in trying to take meaning from the inanity.

meanings_list.meaning: only partly in existence; imperfectly formed
meanings_list.example: Inchoate ideas about the relation of humans to other animals had been discussed since the Middle Ages but the modern theory really began with Darwin.

meanings_list.meaning: necessarily or demonstrably true; impossible to deny or disprove
meanings_list.example: Unless you can provide incontrovertible evidence, I will remain skeptical.

meanings_list.meaning: too sacred to be uttered; defying expression or description

meanings_list.meaning: injustice by virtue of not conforming with rules or standards

meanings_list.meaning: a force that cannot be stopped

meanings_list.meaning: to bow or act in a subservient manner
meanings_list.example: Paul kowtowed to his boss so often the boss herself became nauseated by his sycophancy.

meanings_list.meaning: any long and tedious account of something

meanings_list.meaning: engage in plotting or enter into a conspiracy, swear together

meanings_list.meaning: having good judgement and acute insight

meanings_list.meaning: reluctant to draw attention to yourself

meanings_list.meaning: dependable; inured to fatigue or hardships

meanings_list.meaning: likely to lean towards a controversial view

meanings_list.meaning: change or alter in form, appearance, or nature

meanings_list.meaning: someone new to a field or activity

meanings_list.meaning: not easily perturbed or excited or upset; marked by extreme calm and
meanings_list.example: composure The house shook and the ground quaked, but my dad was unflappable and comforted the family.

meanings_list.meaning: free of guilt; not subject to blame; beyond doubt or reproach

meanings_list.meaning: not able to work, survive, or succeed (also spelled inviable).

meanings_list.meaning: highly or widely praised or boasted about

His traffic violations ran the gamut from the venial to the egregious--on one occasion he simply did not come to a complete stop; another time he tried to escape across state lines at speeds in excess of 140 mph.
All bad novels are bad for numerous reasons; all good novels are good for their verisimilitude of reality, placing the readers in a world that resembles the one they know.
Frank is a veritable life-saver -- last year, on two different occasions, he revived people using CPR.

meanings_list.meaning: change in one"s circumstances, usually for the worse
meanings_list.example: Even great rulers have their vicissitudes--massive kingdoms have diminished overnight, and once beloved kings have faced the scorn of angry masses.

meanings_list.meaning: abusive or venomous language used to express blame or bitter deep-seated ill will
meanings_list.example: His vitriol spewed forth from a deep-seated racisim that consumed his whole life.
While the teacher was more moderate in her criticism of the other student's papers, she was vitriolic toward Peter's paper, casting every flaw in the harshest light.

Jason had dealt with disciplinarians before, but nothing prepared him for the first week of boot camp, as drill sergeants vituperated him for petty oversights such as forgetting to double knot the laces on his boots.
